title: Kylesa brings crushing new sound to The Jinx | savannahnow.com
text:
Photos Photo by Adriana Iris Boatwright
Kylesa
By BRADLEY MULLIS It’s important to know what forces inspire ingenuity in artists, but when posed with this question, Phillip Cope and Laura Pleasants of Kylesa had a surprising response.
“The only thing that I remember that all of us agreed on and never argued about was Fugazi,” Cope said with a determined tone.
Straight-edge pioneer Ian MacKaye’s brainchild was not what one might expect to hear from a prominent sludge metal band, but it only adds to the mysterious vapor Kylesa has cloaked themselves in for the past 14 years.
The group was born in Savannah and since the inception, they have released multiple studio albums and toured both inside and out of the country on multiple occasions, although they’ve remained relatively quiet throughout almost all of 2014.
When asked about this, Cope simply chuckled and replied, “Sometimes it’s good to fade away for a while.”
Nevertheless, the quintet has come roaring out of the shadows with an explosive new release, “Exhausting Fire,” a record that focuses on the broad theme of rebuilding from the loss that was seen on their 2013 effort, “Ultraviolet.”
It’s definitely a change from what Kylesa usually presents, featuring far more ethereal, spacey elements than what we’ve heard in the past. These recent shifts in sound are seen on tracks such as “Moving Day,” “Falling,” “Night Drive” and “Blood Moon,” to name a few. Even though the new album deviates from the standard sludge and riffs the genre is mired in, Cope and Pleasants are not afraid to embrace change.
“We know that coming into every album, there’s going to be somebody who’s not going to be sure about that change,” Cope said. “You can’t expect the whole world to change with you and with us, every record does come out slightly different.”
Pleasants backed this statement by adding, “We didn’t really have the whole debut album, where everyone went nuts over it: (our catalogue) has just been growing and growing.”
And over the past year and a half, Kylesa has grown in leaps and bounds, adding bassist Chase Rudeseal and second drummer John Edwards to the lineup.
“Chase and John are the best fit we’ve had in a while and we’ve really been able to hear it live,” Cope said, speaking on the revolving door the band seems to have with bassists and additional drummers. Pleasants jumped in, adding, “They’re definitely the hardest working.”
Kylesa embarked on a full U.S. tour starting Oct. 6. They will be making a special stop Oct. 9 at their hometown stage, The Jinx, with support from Inter Arma, Indian Handcrafts and Irata. Come watch a new chapter unfold for some of our favorite local rockers.
IF YOU GO
What: Kylesa with Inter Arma, Indian Handcrafts and Irata
When: 9 p.m. Oct. 9
Where: The Jinx, 127 W. Congress St.
Cost: $15
Info: www.kylesa.com
